Introduction

Ganglion cysts are benign pseudocysts formed by connective tissue outpouchings from tendon sheaths, joint capsules, or bursae and contain mucinous fluid.  They are most commonly found on the dorsal wrist and are often asymptomatic.

Pathophysiology



The exact cause of ganglion cysts is unknown, but they are thought to be due to mucoid degeneration of periarticular tissue, leading to outpouching of the connective tissue.  Ganglion cysts often communicate with the underlying joint via a hollow pedicle; fluid is postulated to flow from the joint space to the cyst, and a one-way valve mechanism prevents return flow to the joint.

Risk factors



Factors that increase the development of ganglion cysts include the following:



  • History of joint or tendon injury
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Age 20s-40s
  • Female sex

Pathology



Histopathologic examination of a ganglion cyst shows a mucin-filled fibrous connective tissue sac without an epithelial lining (therefore, ganglion cysts are pseudocysts).

Clinical presentation



A ganglion cyst typically presents as a round, well-circumscribed, mobile cyst overlying a joint or tendon (

image 1
). It occurs most commonly on the dorsal wrist; other common sites include the volar wrist, digits, and feet.  Because it contains mucinous fluid, it transilluminates with a penlight (in contrast to a solid mass that does not transilluminate).



Ganglion cysts are usually painless, and most patients seek medical attention because of cosmetic concerns or fear of malignancy.  However, some patients may experience mild aches.  When the ganglion cyst compresses a nerve, paresthesia or weakness can result.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of a ganglion cyst is usually obvious on inspection and can be confirmed on transillumination with a penlight.  If in doubt, ultrasonography or MRI can confirm the diagnosis, but imaging is rarely necessary.

Differential diagnosis



  • Lipoma (
    image 2
    ):  is a benign neoplasm caused by the proliferation of fat cells.  It rarely occurs on the wrists and does not transilluminate on penlight examination due to its solid nature.
  • Synovial sarcoma:  is a malignancy that presents as a mass adjacent to a joint, usually in a young adult.  Unlike ganglion cysts, it is fixed (not mobile) and does not transilluminate.
  • Tenosynovial giant cell tumor:  presents as a solid mass, typically over the flexor tendons of the hand.  Unlike ganglion cysts, it is fixed (not mobile) and does not transilluminate.
  • Epidermoid cysts (also known as epidermal inclusion cyst) present as smooth, firm nodules with a central punctum, not present in a ganglion cyst.  Because an epidermoid cyst is filled with solid keratin, it does not transilluminate.
  • Gouty tophus (
    image 3
    ):  is a hard, fixed, irregular, subcutaneous collection of uric acid crystals found in patients with advanced gout.  Patients typically have a history of recurrent painful, swollen joints.
  • Rheumatoid nodules (
    image 4
    ):  present as nontender subcutaneous nodules over pressure points (eg, olecranon process); they do not transilluminate.  Patients also have accompanying symmetric joint swelling and characteristic joint deformities (eg, swan neck deformity, ulnar deviation).

Management



More than 50% of ganglion cysts resolve spontaneously and do not require treatment; therefore, asymptomatic cysts can be observed.



Symptomatic (eg, pain, paraesthesia from nerve compression) or cosmetically bothersome cysts can be treated with needle aspiration; however, recurrence is common (half recur within a year of aspiration).  Surgical excision (of the cyst and its stalk) is often necessary for recurrent, symptomatic cysts.

Prognosis



Ganglion cysts are benign lesions with no malignant potential.  Most resolve spontaneously without intervention.  Surgical treatment for persistent or recurrent cysts usually affords excellent outcomes.

Summary



Ganglion cysts (
